Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: A Radar Study of Heavy Rainfall in Taiwan

POR.DRECONTENT:
In a region where heavy monsoon rainfall is affected by mountainous terrain, observations of the processes contributing to this heavy rainfall are crucial. In southwestern Taiwan, the Terrain influenced Monsoon Rainfall Experiment (TiMREX) provided these observations, including a network of radars. In particular, the NCAR S-band dual-polarization Doppler radar (S-Pol) provided the means to address the following objectives: 1) to classify hydrometeor types in intense convective cells and investigation potential elevation-dependent trends in hydrometeor characteristics, 2) to determine the dominant microphysical processes leading to heavy convective rainfall, and 3) compare results with convective cells in other locations characterized by terrain-influenced heavy rainfall.

Through this EAPSI award, the S-Pol data was quality controlled and analyzed for 4 cases during TiMREX, including application of a cell tracking algorithm to determine how these precipitating systems changed as they encountered terrain. By comparing these cases, including those from the Mei-Yi active period and the diurnally forced convection prior, the role of melting ice hydrometeors in producing intense rainfall was highlighted, especially as systems encountered terrain. Additionally, these characteristics were compared to a similar analysis of precipitating systems in northwestern Mexico during NAME.

These analyses contributed to a third of PI Rowe's Ph.D. dissertation, in which the TiMREX cases were described and put in the context of the NAME analysis. Additionally, the relationships built with Prof. Jou's research group fostered continued collaboration after the summer, in which PI Rowe was invited back to Taiwan to present at the 3rd SoWMEX/TiMREX Science Workshop on the work completed during the summer program. Additionally, Rowe continues to read and offer comments on papers from Prof. Jou's students, as was done during the summer in the lab, and discussions continue on the best way to move the research forward toward publication and a potential future field project.

Invited presentation: Rowe, A. K., S. A. Rutledge, and B. J.-D. Jou, 2010: A study of microphysical processes occurring in convection during TiMREX. 3rd SoWMEX/TiMREX Science Workshop  (Oral). Taipei, Taiwan.

Dissertation: Rowe, A., 2011: A polarimetric radar analysis of convective observed during NAME and TiMREX. Ph.D. Dissertation.
